resource.chars: Are we sure this report is by Dirac? Look at the signature: the initials look like R.E., not P.A.M.

Thank you for flagging this, Aileen. This image is indeed the wrong one - it belongs to RR/1950/A3/2, and that one belongs here. We've now asked the developers to switch these around. All the best, Frankie

REFEREE'S REPORT
To the Sectional Committee for Mathematics
Paper by D.R. Bates, A. Fundaminsky & H.S.W. Massey, F.R.S. 
On Excitation and ionizatin of atoms by electron impact. I. 
The Born and Oppenheimer approximations - General theory 
1. Is the paper suitable for reading before a meeting of the Society? 
Doubtful
2. Does it contain contributions to knowledge of sufficient scientific interest for the space 
required? 
Yes
3. Are any portions of the paper, or any illustrations, redundant? 
see under 7
4. Should the paper by published by the Society? 
Yes
5. If so, in the 'Philosophical Transactions' or the 'Proceedings'? (see note on opposite 
page). Transactions see under 7 
6. Or could it more appropriately be published by some other body? 
-
7. Comments or criticisms which might enable the author to improve or correct his statement. 
(Further remarks may be attached.) 
Both papers A.3 and A.4 contain valuable results and should 
certainly be published. In their present form they are on the 
long side for the Proceedings and the suggestion of combining both 
papers into an issue of the Transactions sounds reasonable. 
(The papers are written in a somewhat long-winded manner. 
There is no material that can be regraded as actually redundant, 
but in reading the text one has the feeling that the different 
sources of error are discussed independently one at a time and 
that this involves a certain amount of repetition and also that 
the style of the text would benefit from being somewhat more 
condensed. In this way I believe it would be possible to save 
perhaps 20% in length) but it would be a major piece of work to 
make these alterations. It would seem to me possible, therefore, 
to invite the authors to condense their papers in the way I 
suggest or as an alternative to agree to their going into the 
Transactions. 
Signature R.E. Davies
